comment: After the game my opponent was of the opinion that Black is easily winning after Bh6, but Fritz disagrees. _It seems to me that his opponent was right. After 13...Bh6 14.Ng5 Ngxe5 besides the fact that black is up a pawn, the pin is extremely annoying. If white breaks it with 15.Be3 he also takes the pressure off of black's center and he is more or less just a pawn down for nothing after 15...O-O. If white plays 15.Kb1 f6 16. Ne6 Bxd2 etc. forces an effective queen exchange. However we shouldn't be too smug about the fact that white made the wrong move here. One of the hardest things is when you have the advantage, to choose between several attractive lines and find the one which doesn't allow any counterplay, because first of all you have to see why the other moves do allow counterplay!_
reasoning: The comment provides a detailed explanation of the mistake made by the player, discussing the potential outcomes of different moves and the importance of choosing wisely even when in a winning position.

context: This is a game between Andy Samuelson, 1798. (as White) and Peter Gukhvat, 2143   FIDE. (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Bishop takes on f3
reformulated: It seems that Peter was correct. Black's bishop move to h6 allowed an annoying pin. White's knight move to g5, although giving Black a pawn advantage, did not prevent Black from executing a series of moves that could lead to an effective queen exchange. The pin should have been broken by white's bishop move to e3, which would relieve the pressure on black's center. However, white's decision not to play this move demonstrates the challenge of maintaining an advantage by choosing the line that prevents any counterplay from the opponent.
